prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AB Aur - C18O and 13CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
These observations are designed to probe C18O 2-1 line at 100AU scale in the disc around AB Aur, at the distance of 144pc, so we set the angular resolution to 100/144=0.7arcsec.
We alco include 13CO 2-1 in the setup but with velocity resolution sufficient to provide not only detection but also characterisation of the spectral profile.
Continuum detection will produce anciliary science (peak flux estimated from the literature) but our science is focused on the detection of the C18O line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We wish to achieve velocity resolution of 0.2km/s for the brighter 13CO line to resolve the line profile of FWHM=2km/s with at least 10 elements amd much lower 0.7km/s resolution for the C18O line to optimise detection without gaining significant information about the kinematical structure.

These observations are designed to probe C18O and 13Co 2-1 lines at 100AU scales in the disc AB Aur at the distance of 144pc so we set the angular resolution to 100/144=0.7arcsec. The largest spatial scales of this disc are 8arcsec (Pietu et al. 2005), and our setup can reach this.

We set the sensitivity of our observations to optically thin C18O 2-1 line emission expected from a disc that is 10000 times less massive than its host star. Our model predicts of 180mJy/beam per 244kHz channel for a star at 100pc for a 2Msun star, and we scale this for AB Aur using 2.8Msun and 144pc distance obtaining 120mJy/beam/channel.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We wish to achieve velocity resolution of 0.2km/s for the brighter 13CO line to resolve the line profile of FWHM=4km/s with at least 20 elements amd much lower 0.7km/s resolution for the C18O line to optimise detection without gaining significant information about the kinematical structure.

We set the sensitivity of our observations to optically thin C18O 2-1 line emission expected from a disc that is 10000 times less massive than its host star. Our model predicts of 180mJy/beam per 244kHz channel for a star at 100pc for a 2Msun star, and we scale this for HD34700 using 2Msun and 125pc distance obtaining 115mJy/beam/channel.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Giant planets are more frequently found around stars more massive than the Sun. And yet, our current knowledge of planet formation around intermediate-mass stars is built upon mid- and near-IR surveys, probing the distribution (or lack) of material in the terrestrial planet formation zone. Observations probing the outer disc regions where giant planets are thought to form, are heterogeneous, biased towards the brightest discs, they mainly probe the dust and some probe the gas in the disc surface. Our proposal aims to constrain the largest missing piece of the puzzle - the gas in the disc midplane. Our proposed CO isotope observations are designed to systematically compare the midplane gas densities in the unfrozen disc midplanes (up to 100 AU) in a large sample of intermediate mass Herbig Ae stars covering the full range of observed disc properties. We will look for correlations between the gas density in the giant planet formation zone and a variety of tracers of both the inner and the outer disc, to be used as a beacon for the development of gas dispersal theory in these stars.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
